Amazing game, I shed actual physical tears three times.  If you're looking for a good story and excellent character development with a detailed strategic combat system, this is one of the best I've played. It's easy to restart if you get unlucky on those few fights, loading is fast.

There is a sequal to this  (Third Chapter (TC)) that completes this trilogy.  FC ends in a sort of cliff-hanger, while this game doesn't really. There are issues to be resolved, but you could take a break before TC (Third Chapter).

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1165654312]空之轨迹SC全成就指南[/url]

    本来做翻箱子成就做得心烦不已，但当游戏通关，片尾曲《I Swear》响起时，眼泪还是差点夺眶而出。好的RPG游戏就是有这样的魅力，即使你已对感动司空见惯，对剧情一目了然，你依然会无语凝咽，一如数年前。
  
    矫情完了说下个人觉得游戏不好的地方。
    首先是糟糕的角色成长系统。SC每场战斗获取的耀晶片数量上限和FC一样，都是只有70。而SC的回路从高到低有5类，比FC还要多2类，同时导力器也要多升级一次。另外SC的天使羊不再是固定地点刷，而是伴生，刷羊也要麻烦很多。所以如果你没有花大量时间刷怪，你的回路等级肯定是跟不上商店出新的速度的。回路系统是空之轨迹系列中特别有特色的部分，这种“想要的时候买不起，能买的时候要淘汰”的感觉真是体验很差。而购买耀晶片和钓鱼都是第8章的事了。
    然后是钓鱼系统。钓鱼系统可以说是SC特有的系统，通过钓鱼可以获得大量耀晶片、药物、食材和不错的饰品。但是你要想系统地钓鱼，那就得到第8章。在这之前，钓鱼的作用大概就是SL出几个猛虎之心和做找钓鱼点和钓珍珠草的委托。钓鱼系统更像是一种妥协，作为对成长系统的补足。眼看下一章都大决战了，5级的回路都出来了，结果特么主角们身上还是3级回路？行动力还有特么1级的？个人觉得钓鱼还是蛮有意思的，可惜只能到第8章在王都码头钓到吐。
    说完游戏说下发行商吧，对针对欧美玩家的英文界面和语音我没什么意见，但是每个箱子点2次这个成就真的很影响游戏体验。RPG游戏需要代入感，本来找到箱子开开心心，结果还要再点一次看你调侃，还要点500多次看500多次........我还代入个毛线。
    最后说下个人观点。SC的文本比起FC多了很多，而且还有很多对话用的是俚语，需要一定的英语基础。游戏应该是移植自PSP，所以看攻略记得看下早期PC版和PSP版的不同点，可以弄到一些乱七八糟的东西，比如刻耀珠，提妲的S技等。对于Steam版建议补票不建议玩；一定要玩的话没必要刻意全成就；一定要全成就，如果时间多的话可以二周目再做箱子成就，一周目做实在影响体验。

35334556.review:
Oui MAIS...

Alors attention, je recommande le jeu, mais j'avoue quand même être dans le « variable », car celui-ci a énormément de défauts quand même.
Le premier défaut c'est son aspect « Trails in the sky 1.5 », et quand je dis ça, ce n'est pas parce qu'il innove très peu au niveau du gameplay ou autre, ça je peux le comprendre, mais en jouant à ce second chapitre on a une GROSSE sensation de déjà vu. On tourne dans les mêmes zones, avec les boss aux même endroits quasiment, à se taper des quêtes secondaires très proches (si ce n'est totalement similaires) de ce qui a été fait dans le premier et ce dans les mêmes zones. Sans compter que dans cet opus, faute de repasser toutes les zones du premier chapitre, vous allez aussi y revenir plusieurs fois dans ce chapitre même, et faire beaucoup d'allers/retours (toujours pas de 'voyage rapide').
Heureusement, dernièrement une nouvelle fonction a été ajoutée pour faire aller le jeu plus vite en maintenant la gâchette enfoncée, mais même avec ça, le jeu reste beaucoup trop long. Car non, plus c'est long, plus c'est chiant, du moins ici, j'ai parlé des aller retour, mais je peux aussi parler d'un défaut du 1 qui accentué ici aussi : les zones immensément vides...  Vers la fin c'est encore le pire, c'est vaste mais y'a rien, quelques ennemis, mais peu ou pas d'interaction, c'est totalement vide... Sans compter que beaucoup de niveaux sont labyrinthiques, et vastes, ce qui rend l'exploration très... « meh ». Bref, cet opus est beaucoup plus long, et ce même avec l'option pour accélérer le jeu, mais c'est globalement du vide, du déjà vu et des allers/retours incessants.
Pour finir sur le négatif je parlerais aussi des teams obligatoires qui changent un peu trop fréquemment, vous pouvez avoir jusqu'à 4 compagnons dans votre groupe, mais très souvent vous serez obligé d'en prendre qui sont imposés. En soit ce n'est pas forcément problématique, et c'est assez fréquent dans les j-rpg, cependant ici c'est fréquents,  les items restent sur vos personnages qu'ils soient du groupe ou non (genre vous aviez une orbe spéciale sur un personnage ou un item très puissant mais vous pouvez pas l'avoir avec vous, alors vous ne pourrez pas forcément les transférer non plus) et en plus ils n'xp pas quand ils ne sont pas avec vous. Ce qui fait que très souvent on part à l'aventure avec des personnages que l'on aime pas forcément, et qu'on aime encore moins quand on voit qu'ils ont 10 voir 20 level de retard sur le reste de votre groupe ! Mention spéciale vers la fin, quand en plus de ça j'ai du me taper deux fois de suite un aller retour assez long pour chercher à chaque fois un autre perso obligatoire pour l'avancée de la quête principale, et qui plombe totalement la stratégie que vous aviez avec vos 4 autres...  Sans compter que ça foutait un peu en l'air la crédibilité de la scène, littéralement ça donnait ça :
« hey les gars, les frères de 'machin' sont prisonniers juste devant nous et les boss ne sont pas là, qu'est ce qu'on fait ?
1- on traverse les 10km de la base pour revenir en arrière prendre avec nous 'machin' unstuff et absolument pas au niveau en espérant que les ennemis ne reviennent pas 
2- on y va nous même blindé d'équipement et OP. »

Je vous laisse deviner la réponse....

Autrement, l'histoire est sympa, quelques révélations, du suspense, des quêtes assez sympa et un gameplay qui n'a pas trop changé mais reste plutôt efficace. De nouveaux personnages haut en couleur, des anciens toujours charismatiques...
En gros, les mêmes points positifs que le premier chapitre que je ne vais pas répéter ici, ce qui fait qu'en tant que tel le jeu est recommandable, mais il faut faire fi des défauts du premiers ou ceux cités au dessus....

Bref, vous avez aimé le 1, vous devriez aimer le 2, après tout c'est +/- la même chose.

Les + :
- Nombreux personnages charismatiques
- la narration, l'histoire en général et la crédibilité de l'univers
- un bon système de combat
- une difficulté mieux dosée que le premier

Les  -
- Inutilement long via des zones très vides et trop de labyrinthes (et toujours pas de voyage rapide)
- Trop d'allers-retours, souvent dans des zones en plus déjà explorées dans le 1
- Quêtes secondaires totalement re-pompées du premier opus
- Peu d'évolution dans le gameplay (pas forcément important ici, mais ça accentue cet aspect ersatz du premier)
- Personnages imposés fréquents, qui plombent la team avec leur sous-level.
-------------------------------------

12/20 pour ma part

34650865.review:
Подобно самой Trails in the Sky SC, этот обзор можно считать продолжением обзора первой главы. Все её плюсы относятся и ко второй, и думаю повторяться не стоит.

Прежде всего, нужно сказать пару слов о локализации, ведь она была не менее грандиозной, чем сюжет в игре. 
Перевод, который сопровождался различными внутренними драмами, занял более четырех лет, и в финальной версии скрипта получилось 716401 слово, что, к слову, больше, чем Война и мир - 587287 слов (в английском варианте). Работа была настолько объемной и сложной, что один из переводчиков чуть не покончил с собой (хотя и несколько по другой причине), а главный редактор несколько месяцев работала на износ.

В принципе, коротко сиквел можно описать, как те же щи, да погуще, но благодаря различным улучшениям, и увеличенной продолжительности игры (по сравнению с первой частью), щи получились настолько густыми, что порой можно и ложку погнуть.
Боевая система (наверное самый большой недостаток первой главы, лично для меня), стала интереснее за счет Chain Craft, когда несколько персонажей могут атаковать одновременно, если у них есть достаточное количество CP (Craft Points - местный аналог очков ярости, которая накапливается, когда персонаж наносит удары, или их наносят ему). Кроме того, разработчики сильно урезали количество EP (Energy Points - аналог маны) у персонажей, одновременно повысив интерес к схваткам, и сделав актуальным ближний бой.
Также в игре появились казино (блэкджек, покер, рулетка), и полноценная рыбалка, так что проводить время в игре стало намного интереснее.

Пожалуй, игра приблизилась к статусу идеального сиквела настолько, насколько это вообще возможно. Придраться можно лишь к тому, что поскольку действие происходит в том же королевстве Liberl, посещать предстоит в основном уже знакомые места. Это как плюс (можно встретить множество знакомых персонажей), так и минус (по понятным причинам, хотя использование ассетов первой части и позволило сконцентрироваться на контенте).

P.S. Сохранения первой игры можно импортировать во вторую. Переносится уровень в промежутке от 35 до 40, NPC меняют свою реакцию на игрока соответствующе (если вы им помогли), а обладателям 1-3 классов выдадут дополнительные плюшки (и плюс еще одну, за максимальное количество Bracer Points).

Trails in the Sky SC se constrói em tudo que o primeiro jogo fez, e isso é excelente. A maior reclamação da série é o início lento, mas agora que o mundo do jogo está todo apresentado, é muito mais fácil já jogar as cartas na mesa. E SC faz isso muito bem.

是的，一切都化为了平淡，洛连特的空艇来了又走，曾经的伙伴各奔东西，终有一天，连那场无疾而终的阴谋也将被人遗忘，世界如往常一般运转，永不停歇，时间匆匆流过，带着虚幻得如同梦境的回忆一并消散，唯一真实的，是你，近在眼前的你，触手可及的你，“我的，亲爱的，约修亚。”
无数次试想过这样的清晨，被鸟儿的叫声唤醒时，唇间残存着你的味道，枕边还留有你的气息，厨房里飘来早饭的香味，起床追寻着你的踪迹，却遍寻你而不得时，阳台上传来悠扬的口琴声，原来，你还在我身边
以上，空轨的故事若是在这里完结的话，那也许是最圆满的结局了，恢弘而华美的交响乐般的结局固然令人神往，民谣般平淡的幸福却也弥足珍贵，哪怕这段爱情既无海誓山盟，亦非刻骨铭心，却依然拥有令人动容的力量
以下是一点干货
[h1]宏大的世界观[/h1]
塞姆利亚大陆，新的时代，人们生活是靠一种叫做导力器的技术所支撑着。50年前（即七曜历1150年前后），爱普斯泰恩博士发明了导力器，由此，一场席卷大陆的能源革命——导力革命开始了，它使得大陆进入了空前的发展阶段。另一方面，很多国家为了开发拥有导力力量的兵器而展开激烈的争夺，拥有霸权成为很多国家的意图。在这个错综复杂的时代里，大陆陷入了混乱之中。这个时代，有一个生存于列强罅缝中的独立小国——利贝尔。以利贝尔为舞台的起点，主人公艾丝蒂尔和约修亚将在冒险旅途上遇到各色各样的人物，以成为正式游击士为目标的她，揭开了故事的序幕。以新的世界、新的角色来描述新的故事，这就是开拓时代的物语——空之轨迹
[h1]优秀的代入感[/h1]
JRPG的交互性大致可以分为两部分——玩家操纵的角色与世界的交互，以及玩家与操纵的角色本身的交互，在传统的JRPG里，玩家操纵的角色是世界的中心，角色主动地影响世界，改变世界的命运，但玩家与角色之间的交互却是割裂的，因为玩家并不是拯救世界的英雄，而是一届普通人，与英雄救世的故事间永远隔着一张说书人的嘴，这种故事与现实的落差很难让玩家真正地代入其中；而在轨迹中，世界并非绕着主角旋转，用一句简短的话概括轨迹的主题，那就是“大时代下的小人物”，每个角色都是命运齿轮的一环，角色和玩家一样是无法改变世界的普通人，只能被动地被命运驱动，如同舞台上拿着既定剧本的演员，而玩家的注意力就从改变世界，转移到对人物命运的探索和对人物角色的演绎上了，在这个过程中玩家就会自觉自发地把自己代入角色，跟随角色一起经历冒险，全身心投入到游戏世界中去
[h1]细腻而丰富的细节[/h1]
即便命运无法改变，世界还是会因为你的努力一点点地变化着。这句话用在空轨的NPC们身上我想再合适不过了。每一个做过空轨支线任务的玩家都会感叹于Falcom在NPC身上所花的心思，随着任务的推进，NPC的对话也会随之发生改变，并时不时地与主角发生交集，而当你去深入了解这些NPC时，你会发现，他们不光有着属于自己的故事，而且某种程度上丝毫不逊于主角，在他们自己的故事里，他们也是自己的主角，也会努力过好自己平凡的一生，也会与什么勇敢地战斗，甚至也会顺手拯救一下世界，他们与主角一同成长，最终找寻到了自己的命运，他们不是数据和代码的堆叠，而是有血有肉，拥有灵魂的人，是这个宏大世界的一部分
[h1]总结[/h1]
空之轨迹SC，用一个相当宏大的世界观讲述了一个格局颇小的故事，当然这并不是贬义，世界如此广袤，而我们不过是苍茫天地间的一个小人物罢了，也许连法老控自己也没有想到，有一天“轨迹”会取代“英雄传说”这个主标题成为新系列的的代名词，是的，这不是一个由英雄书写的传说，而是关于普通人如何拯救同伴，少女如何寻回爱人，少年如何得到救赎的故事，他们在命运的洪流中使劲挣扎，最后还是只能随波逐流，没错，世界不以普通人的意志为转移，但是，只要我们一如既往地贯彻自己的信念，终归能够得到成长，而这段冒险将成为我们最美好的记忆，最珍贵的勋章留存心间，鼓舞他人，而世界也会因为我们的努力，向着更美好的方向一点点变化着，这正是电子游戏之于人的意义
引用某位玩家的话游戏的标题意在如此：在天空中飞翔，这是人类对真正的自由的向往。而明白了自己的信念与守护之物，用双手认真地维护并追求自己的梦想，这就如同在天空飞翔一般，是真正的自由。自由之民们的翱翔，将在天空中划下轨迹，指引和守护着那些仍被束缚着的人们，让他们仰望天空，与飞翔的人们心心相连，并走上同样的道路。这大概就是空之轨迹的含义

31526353.review:
[h1]空之轨迹SC——5周目杂感[/h1]

[b]5周目通关分别是PC盗版3次，正版1次，PSP版1次。[/b]

那么为什么是杂感呢？这是因为距离初通的时间太长，很多体悟已经内化了，实在是写不出比较系统的评测了，这里就随便谈谈刚通STEAM版的一些感想吧。

[h1]漫长  OR  冗长[/h1]

不论是轨迹老玩家，还是萌新，几乎都会一致认为SC的剧情在三部曲里面是最冗长的，据我了解，甚至还有铁粉都表示它的剧情“又臭又长”。那么SC到底哪些地方让这些玩家感到不耐烦呢？我认为有以下三点：
第一，几乎一成不变的场景。总体来说，相较FC而言，SC的场景主要是在原来的基础上增加额外的内容。通俗地讲，也就是“老地方”太多了，所占比例保守估计也有50%以上。突出表现在前5章，玩家需要按部就班地把利贝尔每个城镇打一遍，给玩家的感觉，就像是在玩FC的支线任务一样。
第二，剧情高潮部分出现较晚。大部分轨迹玩家认为，SC的高潮应是从第6章“羁绊之所在”开始，而要玩到这一章，则需要不少的时间，加之前5章又有很多支线，因此，很多玩家抱着想看高能的心理，前几章就会玩得比较匆忙。
第三，一部分玩家觉得对话啰嗦。SC完美地保留了FC的优良传统，文字量极为充足，但这一点却为他们所诟病。

[h1]那么SC真的算是最“冗长”的一作吗？——答案是“No”[/h1]

首先，大家需要明白的是，SC是“Second Chapter“的缩写，也就是可以理解为：空之轨迹是一个舞台剧，而SC则是FC拉下帷幕之后的第二幕故事，它们是紧密相连的，这一点在游戏一开始就体现了——可以继承存档，人物菜单打开仍然是FC的界面，并且剧情无缝衔接。另外，还包括引擎、游戏系统的保留等等，就不依次赘述。从这一角度讲，SC应该是整个空轨的第二个大章，这是绝对有区别于其它游戏所谓的第二部作品的。（这就是为什么不叫空之轨迹2）因此，SC保留了大量FC的内容，实际上是说得通的。
然后，对于前几章慢热的剧情，我认为这是Falcom某种讨巧却又不失灵活的设定。一方面，五座城镇刚好对应五名执行者的行动，玩家把他们依次打一遍，岂不也算是理所当然吗？另一方面，前几章虽然缺乏高潮，但其中也有不少有趣的剧情，完全可以弥补这一不足。（Falcom可以节约多少经费啊2333）
最后，文字量巨大这一方面。细化的剧情本来就是轨迹系列的特色，甚至可以说是被众人所推崇的主要原因。剧情是RPG的灵魂，而它当然是靠优秀的文本支撑。有的玩家居然让日系RPG少点字？。。。我就不说什么了。
另外，我个人认为SC的高能应该是从第五章就开始了，而不是第六章。

[h1]令人发指的细节[/h1]

毫不夸张的说，SC里面的各种细节表现，我真的是服得“一塌糊涂”。举例而言，第四章支线任务“搜寻迷路的猫咪”，如果你在FC也找过这只猫的话，会获得祭师之豆。这还不算什么，有的NPC跟主角的对话，也会因为在FC触发的事件而变化。另外，还有一点值得指出，即使是无关紧要的NPC，他们所说的话也比较有意思，不像有的JRPG，NPC就说什么“今天真不错呢，我要抓紧时间干活！”空轨NPC的发言会根据剧情的发展产生明显地变化。并且，空轨的世界观也极为细化，除了表现在主线之外，游戏中有一些小说传记之类的，也写得煞有介事。可以看出，制作组确实是有心要创造一个真正的塞姆利亚大陆。

[h1]并不难听的英语语音[/h1]

为什么一定要单独谈谈这一点呢？实际在游戏的中期，我是把它替换为日语语音的。可见，对于空轨这一游戏而言，日语语音确实优于英语。但我想说的是，英语语音也还是很不错啦~特别是科洛丝的声线，真的有公主的感觉。其他人物总体上也较为接近日语声优，假设没有日语语音的话，我认为英语完全是可以听下去的。毕竟，人家辛辛苦苦在录音室的劳动成果，直接被大家果断地忽略，要说丝毫不可惜，那是不对的。

[h1]空之轨迹——自然流大治愈术[/h1]

“空之轨迹”，看名字就是走文艺路线的游戏。但我个人认为空轨并没有明显的“文艺度”，情感表达也没有文艺向的那种逼格。我看到的只有真挚与自然，毫无矫揉造作之态。具体地来说，空轨的每一个对话桥段都不是走一个单纯的情感路线。比如在很多感人的场景，都不只是单纯地抒情，总有角色说着说着会冒几句逗比的话出来（@奥瓜）。这反映了人物刻画的复杂多样性，复杂性带来真实感，感动源于真实，正是这一连锁效应，让我等玩家老泪纵横。

[h1]Falcom：“我这个老本可以啃十年！”[/h1]

不要误会，对于这款游戏而言，这个标题是褒义的。大家知道，空轨是轨迹系列的处女作，之后的各种轨迹都基本延续了它的游戏系统，叙事风格，世界架构等。姑且不论啃老本对不对，至少有老本就说明空轨这个元老，它是优秀得过分的。同样的一个结晶回路系统，在三部曲中只经过了细微的调整，大同小异，却让玩家乐此不疲，这是很多游戏无法做到的。

[h1]SC多周目仍然存在乐趣[/h1]

我一直以法老控自居，却因为SC流程过长，又没汉化，迟迟没有动STEAM版。后来我发现，打完第一章之后，就已经停不下来了。原因依然有三：1.主动发掘了一些战斗技巧，很多之前苦手的战斗迎刃而解，似乎我是BOSS，敌人是玩家233，觉得轨迹的战斗系统也是值得琢磨的。2.英文对话竟然也很好玩。因为对汉化版文本很熟悉了，所以把英文拿来对照，发现总体上翻译得挺不错的。3.SC剧情代入感太强了。这一点就表现在，你明明知道后面会发生什么，还是会想亲眼再次见证那些事件。（我竟然会被那些黏土小人迷得神魂颠倒）

[h1]菲利普管家：“Falcom jdk的诸位真是魔人啊！”[/h1]

以前专门在动态详细地比较过Falcom jdk和久石让的音乐，这里就懒得详述了。总之，从这一点可以看出，我对轨迹的音乐评价是相当高的。本人不是专门的音乐人，只能以普通听众表示：“轨迹音乐总体应该已经循环上千次了。“噢，还不得不说，它还有一个妙用，就是“听音乐识场景”。即使你俗事繁忙，无法再次玩游戏，但把所有音乐悉数听一遍，也绝对是一场不差的“轨迹之旅”。佛曰：“一花一世界，一树一菩提。”我曰（yuē）：“一曲一人物，一音一感动。“

众人：“通了一遍SC，难道一点牢骚都没有吗？“

当然不是，几个执行者特么要打两遍，攻击方式，召唤小怪都没什么变化，还是有点无聊啊。

最后，该评测于STEAM版空之轨迹3rd发售前一天所撰写，值此纪念。

Don't be fooled - I wish I could rate this game as neutral overall, because it's undeniable that I enjoyed the heaps of time with it and I believe the two current Trails in the Sky games make up one of the best RPG series the genre can offer. I'm unquestionably a fan.
But there are things that make me terribly conflicted about how this sequel goes forward from its predecessor; something I'll save towards the conclusion so I can give what's praiseworthy its due time, because there is PLENTY to remark on that shouldn't turn you away from this experiencing this gem, regardless of my thoughts.

SC brings much deeper combat and more of a challenge. Even normal enemies aren't pushovers anymore and the boss battles are large-scale and take retries. What I appreciated the most was how much the magic system opens up to let you reach those fancy arts hinted in the back of the in-game guide, which I didn't know how to reach in the past game. Once all the tools are in the box, the customability that results is super fun. Party members who switched in and out during the length of FC are now usable for much longer, something that made me glad to rely on my favorites and feel a little guilty for letting some fall to the wayside (Sorry, Tita).

The presentation is immensely stepped up, with a handful of lovely cutscenes paired up with what is still one of the best soundtracks I've heard in gaming (Do yourself a favor and search the OST for 'The Whereabouts of Hope').

I praised the level of detail present in the first game and definitely found it again here, with NPCs continuing their personal stories. There's still enough depth to cause me to miss some quests and collectables since the world is just as vast and complex, even though it is being explored a second time - and perhaps therein lies the root of the problem.

SC does the right thing and changes up the formula a bit, choosing to detach itself from the previous story built by the two main characters and spends much of the time traversing the world over again. The other party members flesh out their backstories in the meantime, which is a fine trade-off to me. But over time it starts to feel like padding, almost. How can this happen if SC's playtime is even longer than the first?

SC becomes less and less spectacular as it shifts its focus on "the next big battle ahead" rather than "the next big adventure to be had", if that makes sense. You're released onto the world with more freedom but much of it has already been seen, learned about, and drank in for all its initial worth. Towards the concluding chapters, to put it rather bluntly and spoiler-free, it entrenches itself in a typical RPG gauntlet of fight after fight. Some storytelling in between connects the dots and wraps up narratives and it manages to deliver a sweet ending, yet it ends so [b]abruptly[/b] - without much fanfare - still memorable, but still proving that it could forget so much of the world I initially fell in love with. It basically left me feeling like I hadn't actually saved it because I was off somewhere else. The characters had practically outgrown the setting and turned their attentions elsewhere. It's a minor qualm, honestly, but it's a strange symptom of wonderfully-written characters shedding their skins to stop being people and more like gods. It's a problem that any other typical JRPG might stumble into whereas I feel Trails in the Sky should be setting itself apart.

This sophomore slump won't shake my faith in playing the third portion of the trilogy when it releases this May. In fact, I can't wait to see if it carries on with renewed energy now that the supervillians I spent chasing for nearly the entirety of this edition are (perhaps?) no more. I want to keep seeing new places and meeting new people, basically getting back to the journey and seeing the focus on character growth take place. It was the number-one positive to me in the first game, and having that feeling of mine take a backseat for the majority of SC is just simply not the same.

Combined with the previous chapter, this is one of the absolute best games I've ever played. Gorgeous soundtrack, an aesthetic that has resisted aging, and a plotline that stays engaging throughout, along with a basically grind-free gameplay arc and some really interesting mechanics - these things are all well and good, but it's the writing (and localisation!) that take the crown. For a jRPG villain to monologue usually means switching off your brain for five minutes while they babble some incoherent Babby's First Negative Utilitarianism half-baked philosophy, and conversely the heroes' response is typically pretty vacuous as well. Not so here, to say the least. And in every scene, there'll be some character saying something that's just *phrased right*, in some hard to define way, and it makes you smile or laugh or cry along with them. 

This game takes the jRPG genre's flaws - edgy protagonists with dark pasts, settings that seem confused about whether to be sci-fi or fantasy, daft plotlines that take forever to get anywhere - and doesn't so much refute them as forgive them, accepting that they're going to do those things and then showing how they can be done right and more than right. Given that this is also in a sense a large part of what happens in-game, I think it's safe to call this one of the great reconstructions. 

It's not often you see a game this good. Play this series.

But the reason I praise the characters so highly, is because the game fell short in a couple of ways.  First the story, while good, felt forced near the end, sometimes lost focus, and was at times not paced very well.  At the end I basically willed my way through the final dungeon without paying much attention.  When I played the first game, I tried to complete as much as possible, and it took me 50 hours, but the story gripped me.  This time, same approach, and the hours jumped to 73 hours, and I felt the game could have kept the story untouched but still shaved 15-20 hours of extra stuff that didnt need to be there. 29025816.review:
The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky Second Chapter (or "SC") is a rarity as far as video games go. Not only is it a direct sequel, but you'd be doing yourself a disservice by not playing the first game (typically called "FC") in the series. Story is the main draw of this series and you'll be lost if you play this one first. It's also worth noting that it's hard to discuss this game without spoiling the first to some degree. With that out of the way, how does it stack up?

FC introduced us to the region of Liberl, its host of characters, its technology, and the geopolitical landscape of the series as a whole. Its gameplay was a bit lackluster and simplistic, but boy did it have a fantastic story. If Final Fantasy is dominated by artists, Trails in the Sky is dominated by writers all the same. Every character, every city, every country, and every extranational organization is chock full of detailed backstory and the characters are brimming with personality. The pacing is slow, but the payoff is far greater than one would expect from a game.

SC continues that tradition and gives us a bigger picture of Liberl Kingdom, its neighbors, and the organization known as Ouroboros which is undermining its stability. As in FC, you will be greeted with walls of text wherever you visit. Hour long story breaks are commonplace but they tell it so well. The localization is impeccable and remarkably witty, characters are deep and intelligent, and character interactions are fantastic and surprisingly detailed. If the game weren't so ridiculously long, you could see any number of interactions by going back and choosing different character combinations for your party. Even the sidequests that aren't basic monster hunts(common) or fetch quests(rare) are story rich -- for sidequests anyway. If you're a "story in games" junkie like I am, you'll absorb every last detail of the world they've created and still be itching for more.

SC also vastly improves the battle system. It has a wider variety of arts (spells), crafts (skills), orbments (augment/spellcraft), and status ailments which make gameplay far more interesting than the original. Battles require more intricate strategy than the original, and a number of optional (sidequest) bosses offer interesting challenges as well. As with FC, the gameplay is not grindy. Experience scales down with level which makes catching up pretty simple -- a mere 10 minutes of grinding is the most you'd ever need, and that's only if you usually run past monsters to begin with. You also get an orbment early on that allows you to avoid monsters entirely. To avoid frustration, you can save anywhere and retry battles upon game over.

The one major downside is that a large amount of the game's content is recycled from the original game. A lot of the SC's music is from FC. Maybe 3/5th of the maps are straight from FC, albeit with new events and quests. Character sprites aside from Estelle and Joshua are exactly the same. It comes with the territory, being a direct sequel, but some might find it disappointing. On the bright side, if you completed FC and carried over your save, you can get a lot of new dialogue (and even some items) based on sidequests you completed in FC.

Speaking of graphics and sound, the sound effects are solid and the voices are clear. The music is catchy but somewhat lacking in variety seeing how FC and SC are a combined 140 or so hours if you do all the sidequests and don't skip cutscenes. The graphics are...graphics. They probably won't wow you, and there haven't been any fixes put in for widescreen, but the sprites are cute.

The final chapter (aka "The 3rd") has been announced for 2017, so it's definitely worth grabbing FC and this game. We'll all get to find out how it ends soon enough!

First off, if you HAVEN'T played the first game yet, then stop reading, go get it, play it, complete it 100%, and THEN get this game and carry it over. It's worth it in more ways than one, believe me, and you won't feel totally lost here!

This is one of my highly recommended JRPG series for a good reason - excellent gameplay mechanics, great in-depth and compelling storyline carried straight over from the first game without missing a beat, and of course the characters - of which you get to control some new characters you didn't in the first game.

You will probably spend a lot of time exploring and talking to NPCs just like in the first game, but that's the beauty of it - the game world is so beautifully done it makes you WANT to explore every nook and cranny of it, it makes you WANT to actually do those side quests. Sure, the graphics are a bit dated, but the level of detail is still overwhelmingly good for a game like this. Oh and there are a few places outside of battle where the environment itself does damage to you/your party, which is new to SC.

I also have to give high marks for the music. A lot of the music was carried over from FC (and hey the music in that game was great too!), but many new tracks were added in as well, especially for the various combat themes.

The combat system is the same as it was in FC, with some nice enhancements to it - the least of which I'll mention is the addition of new crafts (including the Chain Craft system) and new orbal arts thanks to enhanced Orbments. Oh. And attack food. You heard me right. Nothing more satisfying than to chuck a cookie at an enemy and watch it do the damage.

And of course the witty treasure chests are back! I will make a note here that initially when I first played through, they weren't all that unique at first, you had to play through a bit before you saw much in that. It may have changed in the meantime, but just keep that in mind.

28023546.review:
Short version of the review:  If you hate JRPGs, slow-paced JRPGs or non-action games, play something else.  Otherwise, if you can get past a bit of rust you can enjoy a very well explored, lengthy setting with good customization and competent combat that has related titles still releasing as of 2016.  There isn't much in the genre that can compete with this series in terms of scope, interconnectivity and character development.  This game also taught me that force-feeding your angriest friend tomato sandwiches will allow them to kill anything.

Long version of the review: This recommendation comes with a few caveats: First, play the first chapter first.  If you didn't make it through that, you definitely won't make it through this.  In a more general sense for the series, Trails in the Sky is a very long trilogy with a sort of plodding pace to it and antiquated system- if you even have to ask if that's your thing, it probably isn't.  This is a game that nearly made the localizer nearly kill himself, it's got more text than more books and if you want to do more than scratch the surface you can expect a playtime approaching mine.

SC continues on almost exactly where the first chapter left off- both plotwise and mechanics-wise.  They quickly update you on what's changed in what is actually one of the more cut-throat tutorials I've ever seen.  I don't recommend starting on hard like I did, and I strongly urge no one to start on nightmare- you will be stuck a long while grinding and possibly crying in the prologue if you do.

The game eventually expands into a partially de-lineated JRPG wherein the sidequests and talking multiple times to everyone is the focus.  Completing the sidequests is for the most part worth your time, as it gives much needed money and equips which random encounters do not provide, a great deal of dialogue and sometimes insight into the setting.  Some of the objectives to maximize quest rewards are pretty obtuse, and even missing talking to a single person between important plot points can be a serious frustration.

Trails in the sky is fairly well seperated into ten chapters with either a different focus on geographical location or situation.  While there is a lot of re-used assets from the first game, part of the appeal is the familiarity mixed with some of the new stuff, and continuing relationships with the characters your character strives to protect.  Given the sheer volume of quests, lack of auto-travel and length of the game, however, you may be inspired to take breaks.  I certainly did.

The combat in this game was fairly novel for its time way back in 2003, but runs into limitations when being pushed.  Eschewing turn-based combat for delay-based actions makes speed and numbers relevant, but also hyper-relevant.  When the game robs you of party members or ambushes you or surrounds you, your options are very limited and generally you're going to be relying on luck.  While this can be nice and tense and result in memorable fights, once you get down a character or two you're probably just waiting to die.  On the harder difficulties, cheese is kind of mandatory, especially since grinding isn't really an option.  There's a bit of depth in how one, say, spams the equivlent of limit breaks known as S-Crafts, since they generate a lot of delay, but once your game plan is set you generally stick to it.

Orbments (Basically a fancy magic pocketwatch with replaceable magic stones), equipment and character selection do allow for some interesting customization, but a lot of the more interesting options are only provided if you keep up religiously with sidequests.  Towards the end of the game however, it's easy to realize that most of the gems fall into certain colours and that due to the action economy there's a few must-haves for act time that you can't really live without that your options almost become more limited.  Customization is also fraught with complications like leaving your good gems with characters that leave temporarily or just the fact that you can't unequip everyone at once (or equip them if you get them during a cutscene/fight).  Being able to save anywhere and the sheer number of slots available help alleviate this, however.

The closest thing to a crafting component to the game is the cooking system.  Food is obnoxiously powerful and generally much more economical than any equivelent items once you fork out an initial investment.  I personally love incongruous attack item spam in these sorts of games, so being able to defeat many early and difficult encounters by throwing stale cookies and meatballs at them was very enjoyable for me.  For a long time there are logistical concerns about what food you bring and cook, but towards the end of the game it's fairly trivial to make a few dozen tomato sandwiches and shove them down your character's gullets until everything is dead.  Even the rather terrifying optional battle was won through liberal use of tomato sandwiches with a side of cheese.

On the subject of cheese, the villainous elements of the game tend to fall on the cartoonish side.  This isn't exactly strange for the genre, and it's called out by the much more well-rounded player character cast to some degree, but some of the dialogue is so flamboyant it'll make you roll your eyes around and around.  There's plenty of other goofiness and sort of misplaced levity at times, but given that the main characters are teenagers and the localization is pretty well done I'd say it's not really out of place.  There's some good dialogue, a tremendous number of characters and unique lines, consistent characterization including growth and reaction to different events over time... when you build a comparable relationship to any given airship engineer that you'd expect to build with the Yarl of Whiterun in Skyrim, you know they've got something a bit special.  It's on a level that isn't easily matched in terms of concurrent narratives that you can explore, and that's pretty rad.  It just takes a lot of time, is all.

Graphics are dated but serviceable.  Lack of camera rotation and re-used tiling in certain places can be a pain, and it's part of the generation of JRPGs that loaded in long-ass spells and special moves to show off that particle effects were a thing.  Very little looks outright bad or indistinct, and some of the monster animations and designs are so bizarre they manage to come off as horrifying.  The cutscenes are pretty good for their time however, and have excellent detail and fairly good length the odd time they show up.  The final cutscene in particular is very elaborate, and I appreciated how it conveyed the scope of the aftermath of the conflict.

The music is incredible as always- it's Falcom.  Problems arise from the fact that the number of tracks don't really match the game length- as much as I love the combat theme, they needed a bit more variety, especially since a lot of themes are variants of "The Whereabouts of Light" or "Golden eyes, Silver Will"- while I love variants and leitmotifs, more was needed.

In summary, there aren't a lot of games that can match the scope of this duology and its continuation beyond simply because of breadth of content, depth of optional storylines and relationships with characters and customization options.  The tone is a bit juvenile and anime, but if you want something heartwarming and intricate it certainly has its moments.  If you wanted to sink a hundred hours plus into an old-fashioned JRPG series, I'd probably point you here first, and for that this game and its predecessor has my approval.  Looking forward to The 3rd.

Je viens de terminer le deuxième jeu des Trails in the Sky et voici mon avis à propos des deux jeux. 

Points positifs : 

- Le système de combat au tour par tour, qui inclut une notion de distance et de zone, est très bien pensé.
- Le système de personnalisation des habiletés des personnages est également bien fait. Avec les quartz, il est soit possible d'augmenter les caractéristiques des personnages (force, points de vie, etc.), soit possible de donner des statuts négatifs aux attaques physiques (sommeil, pétrification, etc.).
- La difficulté est généralement bien dosée si on fait suffisamment de batailles, qu'on porte attention aux statuts négatifs infligés par les ennemis et qu'on fait la plupart des quêtes.
- Il est possible d'éviter et de fuir et d'éviter des combats facilement, ce qui est pratique quand on est trop fort dans une zone ou quand on veut simplement faire des quêtes sans avoir un combat aux cinq secondes.
- À certains moments de l'histoire, les personnages sont mandatés à faire des petites enquêtes, ce qui est intéressant.
- Le but du jeu n'est pas de sauver le monde, contrairement à ce que l'on voit dans bien d'autres jeux du genre. L'action du jeu se limite dans un royaume et dans ses environs. Les enjeux deviennent importants, mais jamais planétaires. 
- Les villes et villages sont différents de ce que l'on retrouve dans les autres RPG. Généralement, ce qui distingue les villages dans les RPG est la zone géographique (déserts, eau, froid, forêt, etc.). Dans ce jeu, ce qui distingue les villes et villages peut être un aréna, une zone portuaire plus importante, une zone de boutiques, etc.  

Point négatifs :

- Les dialogues sont long et répétitifs, surtout vers la fin quand on est impatient de terminer le jeu.
- La durée pour faire les quêtes avant qu'elles échouent n'est pas précise et est souvent trop courte. J'aurais aimé pouvoir faire un bout d'histoire, une quête, un bout d'histoire, une quête, mais parce que j'avais échoué des quêtes à cause d'un délai arbitraire, je me sentais obligé de les faire dès qu'elles apparaissaient, ce qui était une vraie corvée.  
- Les éléments cachés sont trop faciles à rater. Pour avoir une arme ultime, il faut quelque chose comme 14 objets et certains objets sont faciles à rater, car on les a quand on parle à un personnage X après un événement Y, ce qui est impossible à deviner sans guide. 
- Dans les combats, la magie ne sert pas beaucoup, compte tenu qu'il y a un délai entre le moment où on lance le sort et où le sort prend effet, ce qui désavantage la magie par rapport aux autres types d'attaques. En plus, la magie est rarement plus forte que les techniques. 
- Il y a des plantages sur certains ordinateurs : si je n'avais pas eu deux ordinateurs, en ce qui me concerne, je n'aurais jamais pu terminer le jeu. À certains moments, sur mon ordinateur portable, l'écran devenait noir et j'étais incapable de faire quoi que ce soit car je ne voyais plus rien, y compris les menus. À d'autres moments, sur mon ordinateur de table, mes personnages figeaient à des endroits précis et n'étaient plus en mesure d'avancer. Tout cela est arrivé tard dans le premier et le deuxième jeu, ce qui rend le remboursement impossible. 

Après avoir joué à ce jeu, j'en retiens généralement une bonne expérience. Est-ce que je le recommande? Oui, mais seulement à ceux qui sont prêts à vivre avec les défauts du jeu. En ce qui me concerne, ça faisait longtemps que je n’avais pas apprécié autant un jeu, malgré tout. Si tous les défauts avaient été corrigée, ça aurait été le jeu parfait!

And unlike with Trails of Cold Steel 2 which felt the need to present ever-more-powerful arts and S breaks that eventually bordered on the absurd and resulted in a largely broken system where pretty much every boss but the final boss could be one or two-shotted, SC kept its balance which I appreciate - Even if it doesn't make much sense that Estelle has smacked a guy directly in the face 50 times with a metal staff and he's still standing. Anyways, the story is where the game stepped up to the plate, and it hit it out of the park. Where it could have been sappy it was serious, while not taking away from the obvious emotional themes running through our protagonist's head. It did a lot to expand the world, and make you constantly want to know more about the world and other countries -which thankfully you get to explore more in Cold Steel, and if it's ever localized, the Crossbell arc.

27163165.review:
Это, наверное, одна из самых лучших игр жанра jRPG, доступных в Стиме
Для начала расскажу о минусах:
-Поломанные ачивки, а конкретно ачивка с прочтением книг. Мелочь, но все равно неприятно.
-Нет опциональных данжей с боссами. Опять же мелочь, но после игр серии Final Fantasy как-то не хватает.
-Отсутствие перевода на русский. Для понимания всего, что в этой игре происходит, вовсе не надо обладать неверноятным знанием английского, но это все-таки стоит отнести к минусам.
На этом минусы для меня заканчиваются. Теперь расскажу о плюсах:
+Отличный сюжет. Он действительно хорош, персонажи прописаны замечательно, злодеи круты и повороты внезапны.
+Качество порта. Это пожалуй первый порт, в который удобно играть на клавиатуре. Оптимизация так же не страдает, в общем порт очень и очень качественный. Очень порадовала фича с автоматическим движением мышки, невероятно удобно.
+Боевка. В ее основу заложен классический пошаговый бой, плюс добавлены перемешения по полю и дальность скиллов. К ней у меня тоже претензий нет, все выглядит очень и очень органично. Отдельно стоит упомянуть про сами скиллы. Посредством левелинга получаются только сигнатурные скиллы и лимит-брейки. Остальные необходимо получать, вставляя самоцветы в специальные устройства. У каждого персонажа разные ограничения на самоцветы, поэтому и наборы скиллов у каждого персонажа разные. Лично мне эта система очень понравилась, хотя для того, чтобы получить таким образом что-то реально мощное придется погриндить.
+Саундтрек. Опять же на высшем уровне, некоторые треки вполне можно добавить в свой собственный плейлист.
+Графика. Очень радует глаз, рисовка качественная, да и анимация замечательная.
+Ну и конечно же фирменные юморески от Оливера.

В итоге, по моему мнению, получилась одна из самых лучших jRPG всех времен. Эта игра, несомненно, стоит своих денег.

JRPGs hay muchos y en muchos de ellos suele prevalecer el viaje, la aventura. Otros hasta se toman el lujo de explicar una historia, con personajes que evolucionan a lo largo de esta.

La duología Trails in the Sky (y la saga Trails en general) es de las que se centra en explicar una historia, la historia de unos héroes, valga la redundancia. A pesar de que la primera parte del título tenga un nombre tan genérico, The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky SC es ambicioso en su argumento y aunque pueda parecer una historia típica pero muy bien contada, no es más que una de las leyendas que forman una historia global de hasta ahora 7 juegos, el octavo en camino de anuncianse. Sólo hemos visto la punta del iceberg y todavía quedan varios títulos de la saga por ser traducidos para poder encontrar más motivos por los que recomendarlos, pero Trails in the Sky FC/SC ya nos avisa de que esta no es una saga de entregas independientes, como podría ser Final Fantasy.

El continente de Zemuria está vivo y todo lo que pase en el Reino de Liberl va a tener consecuencias en otras naciones;
se va a liar parda, y sólo vamos a ver una pequeña parte en estos dos juegos.

Recomiendo FC y SC a los que busquen un mundo con mucho trasfondo, personajes que evolucionan a pesar de mostrar una simpleza y estereotipado al comienzo (sobretodo en FC, siendo el "prólogo" de la duología) y a los que les gusten los JRPG con toque táctico, al estilo Disgaea.

Around October last year, my best friend convinced me to buy a couple of games in the Steam autumn sale, called The Legend of Heroes Trails in the Sky, and its sequel, Trails in the Sky SC, which was just localized. It took me a few months to get to actually playing and completing them due to various reasons, but now that I did (and stayed up till 6 in the morning to finish SC), I have one thing to say. It was all so, SO worth it. 

Where do I even start? The story is an amazing example of tricking you into thinking it's a run of the mill JRPG, when it's anything but. It's an intricate, deep, well-thought out and wonderful story, with some of the best world building I've ever seen. (NPC's with their own stories isn't something you come across every day.) The characters are so charming, lovable, well-written, and so well-developed, including even the villains, which honestly feel more like well-intentioned extremists at times rather than outright villainous. The OST is simply marvelous, whether it be boss battle themes (like the one down here) or emotional tracks, it all fits so well and sounds amazing. Sure, the game looks outdated at first glance, but it sure as heck doesn't feel that way, and the battle system is quite easy to grasp, especially if you're not used to turn-based games. 

Overall, Trails in the Sky was one of the best video games I've experienced in quite a while, and it was worth every minute and so worth buying. It was awesome and amazing, and I can't recommend it enough.

26032035.review:
The niche but well-regarded JRPG title, once exclusive to Japan, was finally ported and localized in the US in the form of a PSP release by XSEED games. It told the story of Estelle Bright and her adopted borther Joshua, as the two sought to become full time bracers as well as uncovering a mysterious conspiracy that would send their kingdom into chaos. The sequel to Trails in The Sky, SC(Second Chapter), after years of waiting and an additional year long delay, had had many fans hungry for a continuation of the story; a burning desire to return to its immersive world,  and the incredibly charming old-school RPG gameplay surrounding it. SC finally arrived in 2015 of October for PSP, Vita, and PC for digital download. It is a awesome and satisfying sequel to the first chapter. One thing I was disappointed about SC was that it takes place mostly in Liberl (again), and it felt repetitive to revissit the same places over again, just with replaced dialogue and cutscenes. But it didnt worry me too much, as the game does the most with what recycled resources there are. 

Speaking of dialogue, this is perhaps my favorite part of the game: XSEED's awesome localization of the script. I dont know if the characters actually spoke like this in the original Japanese, but the way they speak in English is chock full of personality, quirkiness, and humor. The English version does a fantastic job of making each character's personality distinct. Just through their dialogue alone you could tell which character is which without looking at their portrait. Credit goes to both Andrew Dice and Jessica Chavez (and other people probably whose names arent mentioned), for pouring hundreds of hours translating the massive gigantic story. Trust me, this game is GIGANTIC.

 To go off on a short tangent here, XSEED is a small but passionate Japanese localization company that does its best to bring awesome but not very well known franchises outside Japan to overshore. Because of the low sales of the games they localize, they are financially shaky. Not to mention they are translating the Legend of Heroes series' giant amounts of dialogue with little financial benefit in the end. I can not say this enough. PLEASE support the official releases of these titles in North America or elsewhere. We want XSEED to get credit where it's due. They are a tiny company but passionate about what they do, and they deserve whatever rewards they can muster. It's because of them we get to play this gorgeous series in English, with awesome personality-filled dialogue.

Trails in the Sky SC has an awesome story. Though a little on the cliche side, you will fall in love with almost every character. Gameplay allows for very personal customization options suited to your preferred playstyle for each character. It's fun immerse yourself in the world and go exploring. It's everything the traiditonal RPG purist or casual player will have fun with. Would I reccomend this game? Yes.

- Die Stärke des Spiels ist wie der Vorgänger die Geschichte über Estelle. Wie eh und je mit tollen Dialogen mit Estelle, Olivier und vielen anderen Characteren. 
- Der Soundtrack wird an manchen Stellen mit neuen Songs erweitert und gefällt mir noch etwas besser als im Vorgänger (mit Ausnahme des Standard-Battle-Themes).
- Fordernde Kämpfe sowie mehr Abwechslung und Variation in Sachen Kämpfe und Ausrüstung verglichen mit First Chapter.
- Man kann sich recht früh am Spiel zwischen 2 Characteren als Begleiter entscheiden. Jeder hat individuelle Dialoge. Später hat man freie Wahl.
- Epischer, mehrstufiger und kniffliger Endboss-Kampf & Endboss-Theme
- Es gibt ein episches abschließendes Ende, keinen Cliffhänger wie zuvor.
- Gewohnt gut funktionierende PC-Fassung.

Was mir weniger gefällt / Negativ:
- Wie im Vorgänger kann man einige Bonusziele sehr leicht verpassen.
- Kapitel 2 - 4 sind in Ihrem Ablauf, ohne hier näher in die Details zu gehen,  recht vorhersehbar.
- Gegen Ende des Prologs ist der Schwierigkeitsgrad wirklich unfair. Die Auffassung ist gewiss nicht untertrieben, vgl. übernächster Absatz.

Neutral:
- Die Spielwelt und Musik des Vorgängers wird fast vollständig wiederverwertet. Das muss zwar nicht unbedingt etwas Negatives sein, aber man hat einen gewissen Teil der Spielwelt eben schon gesehen oder gehört.
- Sehr lange Spielzeit von etwa 90-140 Stunden (Doppelt so lang wie der Vorgänger), mehr Kapitel und zusätzliche Nebenbeschäftigungen (Fischen, Casino). Dies erklärt auch den höheren Preis im Vergleich zu Teil 1.

Warnung:
- Erneut empfehle ich den Schwierigkeitsgrad Schwer muss jedoch zugleich davor warnen. Der "Prolog" hat einen der schwersten Endgegner der Spielgeschichte. Auf Schwer braucht man Glück, Tatik und Vorbereitung (am besten Komplettlösung für den Prolog zu Rate ziehen). Der Rest des Spiels ist anspruchsvoller als der Vorgänger, jedoch noch fair.

Fazit:
Wem den Vorgänger gefallen hat der muss dieses Spiel einfach spielen. Etwas anderes kann ich hierzu einfach nicht mitteilen. Die Kämpfe sind leicht fordernder und interessanter als bisher. Wem der Vorfänger eine Spur zu leicht war dem wird das Spiel sicher gefallen. Über die Geschichte habe ich schon das wichtigste gesagt. Meine Erwartung daran wurden jedenfalls in der 2. Hälfte des Spiels mit Sicherheit übertroffen.

25743265.review:
200 hours later and I feel that I have to review this game.

In general, I enjoy stories with crazy twists and things going to places where I do not expect. Case in point: Novels like 9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors and Danganronpa 2, while they're not JRPG's definitely fulfill the crazy story criteria, and I love them.

Every now and then, I enjoy indulging in some generic "tropey" storytelling, as long as the execution is interesting enough for me to care. This is Trails in the Sky. This is also the moment that I'm telling you to start with the first game in case you're interested, simply because First Chapter and Second Chapter are one story, the Estelle & Joshua arc. Also, in case you played the first game and you didn't liked the story, you shouldn't really bother with the second. Contrary to the fans' belief, while the story does get better it doesn't get less generic and tropey, so if those points were your turn-off for the first game they will be your turn-off for the second one too.

Gameplay-wise here's what you'll expect: Turn-based combat, a magic system kinda similar to how FF7 materia work (you link Quartz together to use spells and you slot them in a certain way on an Orbment - the device where you place Quartz on - to use spells you couldn't use before), no random encounters but you can see the enemy roaming and choose to approach from behind (preemptive attack) or avoid him altogether, grinding is possible but really unecessary and discouraged. The game is OK challenging in normal mode, hard as steel in Hard mode and "you gotta be batshit insane to play this" in Nightmare (it's what I'm currently doing). 

Although I already mentioned story elements, it's worth noting that the game is text-heavy. I mean REALLY text-heavy. Here's a [url=http://i.imgur.com/TIqUNcJ.jpg]picture[/url] to understand. Now, I'm not saying that more means that you'll like it. I'm saying that reading dialogues in JRPG games shouldn't be an issue for you.

Last, but not least, the music. Fans complained that the first chapter lacked in the music department, which I have to agree given the kind of soundtrack people in Falcom are [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TXHtkHlLcxQ]capable[/url] of [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z3VSYWmbJFg]composing[/url]. And oh they did, the absolute madmen.

All in all, a solid game if you don't mind generic stories (I don't believe that generic is inherently bad but that's just me) and turn-based combat, coupled with "Falcom-tier" soundtrack. I'm giving it 2 thumbs up because I got exactly what I expected and 200 hours and 2 playthroughs later I'm still enjoying it.

Trails in the Sky the 3rd is scheduled to be released in the West for the first time around spring 2017. Just adding that up. Also, the games "Trails of Cold Steel" that are currently available for Playstation 3 and Vita are part of the same saga, but the stories aren't related.

“It’s done.” “Yes Mr Frodo, it’s over now.” - Frodo and Sam. I feel like I just ran a marathon.

I had a lot of acclaim for the first game in this series. Overall it was a pretty good game, a few flaws but overall pretty good.

It’s hard to say the second installment is good, which is a pain because parts of this game are really good.

+ The characters are still gernerally pretty great. You find yourself really wanting to root for the characters.

+ Some cool cinematics that give the game some much needed depth.

+ Some really interesting side quests, like the quest that reveals the backstory of Lila, Mayor Maybelle’s maid.

However when you look at the game as a whole, you can only think, what the heck where the devs thinking?

- The pacing is aweful. There feels like a neverending bunch of crap between major story points.

- The asset reuse for a new 60+ hour game is a bit much. I pretty much felt like I played litterly the entire first game before really getting to new content. - Combat is just bad overall.  The combat system is just really imballanced, and the only way they seem to be able to cause a real challenge is by making your skills and abilities not work, or simply turn fights in to a grind fest. You can almost be assured that when you are in any kind of harder monster or boss fight none of you crowd control and generally things like speed down do not work. Also some bosses have bull skills like being able to kill your or phase you out of existance even if you have full guard. Also just like the first game if you accidently activate an S-Skill there doesn’t seem to be a way to deactive it, you have to use it.

-There are times where things go way too long between being able to save.

- If you thought the ending of the first game was tough, you ain’t seen nothing. I’m not sure who thought several hours of grinding boss fights at the end was going to be fun. If I hadn’t put like 120 hours in to the two games combined I would have bailed a long time ago, and almost did.

TLDR;
I love parts of this game just like the first. It has a lot of the same flare, humor, good writing and great characters. 

Too much asset reuse, boring bad quests, bad pacing, and crazy design dessisons just make the game anti-fun. If you value you sanity, do not play. The payoff is not worth it.

23155471.review:
[h1] The Dream Continues [/h1]
In my review of Trails in the Sky First Chapter (FC), I felt inclined to refrain from mentioning any criticisms, largely because the only criticisms I had were nit-picky. I was full of praise as to how this game differs from any other JRPG I had played prior to the games in the Legend of Heroes series. As result, I purchased Trails in the Sky Second Chapter (SC) almost immediately after it was released on steam. In terms of gameplay and the overall mechanics in SC, they remain largely identical to FC and therefore there is no need to dwell on them in this review. I recognise that this review probably will not mean much to those who loved FC as it is likely they have already bought and finished SC. Likewise if you did not like FC, then I would be surprised if you are considering buying SC. 
I can confidently say right off the bat that FC and SC together are among the best games I have ever played, with SC expanding on the greatness that was FC.
The consequence of playing and adoring FC is that I had extremely high expectations going into SC. Whilst those expectations were entirely met, this time around my review cannot be so clear cut as it was for FC. In order to review this game fairly and without bias, I intend to mention a noticeable flaw I identified because it would be ignorant to ignore it.

*No spoilers* 

[h1] Story [/h1] 
The story in SC is definitely a step up from FC, with enough plot twists to make you run around the room in excitement... I know I did. Every main character is developed from the first game in a meaningful way. Even Estelle develops from a largely clumsy, hilarious and enthusiastic person to a more mature... clumsy, hilarious and enthusiastic person.  

Like FC, the story is split into a series of well-structured chapters, however in SC the game is separated into 9 different chapters rather than the 4 main chapters in FC. As expected the story neatly follows from FC. My main criticism of the game is based on the first 4 chapters. The problem with these chapters is that by chapter 2, the story gets largely predictable with the similar kind of occurrence happening in each chapter (I'll spare the details). Of course the predictability ends soon after the 4th chapter. This may not necessarily be a problem for many who have played SC, but it did get a tad repetitive, especially in conjunction with the side quests which do not vary that much. However, this is largely where my noticeable criticisms end and I appreciate this is largely a subjective criticism. 

To this day, the 5th and 6th chapters of SC were... Some of the best segments of a game I have played in my entire life... And I have played a lot of games! 
Although I will not describe the contents of those chapters, they were the most deeply engaging, emotional and thrilling parts of a game I have ever played, galvanizing anyone into adoring the game. I wish I could describe the details.
The ending of the game is satisfying. That is my greatest hope for any sequel of a JRPG. It is far too easy for games to conclude having left more questions than answers. Although there is a cliff-hanger which sets up the Third Chapter (TC), it is not the kind of cliff-hanger which leaves a lack of fulfilment and a taste of disappointment. As I mentioned to a friend, I would not mind if the Third Chapter is never localized... That’s not to say that when it is finished being localized I won't play it. I will buy it on the day it is released! Hell I will stay up all night with a countdown clock till its release! Nevertheless, what I am concluding is that the Second Chapter had a satisfying ending; it felt like the hours I had put into the game actually meant something significant in the end, rather than leaving a lingering anticipation for what happens next. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
There is very little which can be said about gameplay other than it is almost identical to the First Chapter. In my review of FC, I mentioned the way in which gameplay differs from other JRPG's I am familiar with such as games in the Final Fantasy franchise. This difference remains the same in SC. The main new mechanic in SC is the ability to combine attacks with different characters (Chain attacks). They were a nice new addition to the game, but nothing revolutionary. If you loved the gameplay and the battle system in FC, then it follows that you should feel the same about SC. 

[h1] Music [/h1]
The first thing I wanted to know when I bought the game is how the music would differ from FC. I have invested hours into listening to the music of FC outside of the game and I will probably spend many hours more listening to FC's OST. I can gladly say, the soundtrack in SC is a masterpiece - my favourites being: 'The Dream Continues,' 'Silver Will' and 'I Swear.' I do not recommend listening to any of the soundtrack before playing the game, solely because of the emotional effect they have within the game. None of the pieces are overused or underused. The first thing I did after finishing the game was search for the pieces on YouTube. 

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
FC and SC felt like a dream. I say this as the two games felt like perfect games with very few flaws. Although I stated my noticeable criticism of SC, it is insignificant when looking at the overall standard of the game. The characters remain as funny as they were in FC, the story is brilliant, the music is sensational and the localization is without flaws. Only Aidios knows why this game is not as popular as it should be. I have always felt that it is the most well-made games which receive the least credit. I am now in the process of playing Trails of Cold Steel. As for the Third Chapter, I can only hope the dream continues. 

[h1] 9.5/ 10 [/h1]

23112287.review:
I'll start off by saying that having played through the first one, this game is SOOO LONG with more than double the playtime of the original. That being said, I don't regret a single hour of this beautiful sequel.

Although the gameplay hasn't significantly changed much from the original, the magic (orbment) and skills (crafts) system has been expanded upon tremendously. The original three pages of magic has been expanded to five; introducing newer strategies to the abundant amount of character choices. The new skill, chains, finds itself to be useful in some scenarios. These additions made the gameplay always refreshing, seeing that I've played more than 100 hours fighting shiny pom poms.

The team system has significantly improved since the first chapter. This shouldn't be a surprise since the entire game revolves around changing teammates and parties, but first let me explain the difference. (Minor Spoilers) In the original game, two characters (Joshua and Estelle) would always be playable characters while each chapter offers two other characters that make up the rest of your party. Each chapter changed the party and thus your team strategy. The game struck a nice balance of difficulty and adaptation except for the last chapter. The chapter which allowed you to make your own team with all the characters you've met along the way wasn't very balanced. The enemy encounters grew extremely repetitive and boring, and [spoiler]the final boss could be described in the same manner.[/spoiler]

However, the second chapter struck a good balance while letting the player create a team themselves. Although the first chapter was pretty repetitive since your options were limited, I found difficult monsters and interesting monster attacks that kept the combat intriguing. In general, bosses were more interesting and carried a 'mood' about them. Again (minor spoilers), but the last chapter's boss fights were beyond amazing. By far the bosses and 'road monsters' are the best thing about Trails in the Sky SC's gameplay.

Now a small paragraph about the OST. I read on a forum somewhere that the OST for SC was supposed to better than FC. For the majority of the game, I questioned this opinion since it reused alot of songs from the first game. But all of a sudden near the end of the game, the soundtrack dramatically improved with new songs. The credits song gave me chills. Good job music writers, although I'd appreciate if the same songs weren't used every single time in the first few chapters.

Retrospectively, I should've talked about the graphics/textures of the game in the first paragraph. If you've gotten used to the graphics in Trails in the Sky FC, then this game should be no problem. Although walking through the same landscape as Trails in the Sky FC is a bit boring, some of the new landscapes introduced are beautiful and well worth it.

Story and characters. Amazing. Marvelous. Hella GOOD JOB Nihon Falcom. Pretty much every character gets their back stories introduced and expanded upon. Some scenes are so fantastic that they definitely should've made a scene select option in the menu. The hidden nature of the Society and some of the plot twists make the game so much more interesting and hooks you back in the next day even after you've spent one entire day playing the game. Afterall, story and character development feels like such a lovely reward after defeating bosses with a sliver of health remaining. By far, Estelle's character development was done beautifully well. My only complaint is that you have to switch around characters in your party to obtain extra dialogue which sometimes can't be done without grinding character levels (looking at you, last area last chapter). Otherwise, the story is great if you enjoy anime stories with a touch of the shounen genre.

Honestly if you enjoyed Trails in the Sky FC, then this game is a must buy. As anyone does, I EXTREMELY HIGHLY recommend playing through the first game first. This game assumes you've already played through FC, so there are many spoilers and the difficulty curve is quite steep in the beginning. If you haven't tried either, I'd recommend buying the FC on sale and testing the waters before you delve deep into this trilogy.

I'm writing this review as I just finished this game and it feels great. However, I can see in the future I'll be impatient and sad waiting for the third chapter. Xseed, you better deliver the damned third chapter or I'll be coming over there with a Bo Staff.

[h1]ACHTUNG: Diese Review wird Spoiler enthalten![/h1]

"Unconsciously you've been trying to think of it as someone else's problem, to get away from it. A lot of people do that ..."
Bevor ich hier erklären möchte, wieso ich dieses Spiel für eines der besten Spiele aller Zeiten halte (Zusammen mit First Chapter), möchte ich hier auf Spoiler hinweisen. Mit 40 - 60 Stunden Spielzeit und einer Menge an Storytwists und Charakteretablierung, ist es für mich leider unvermeidlich. 
Zuallererst: Wer First Chapter bereits nicht mochte, wird auch dieses Spiel hier nicht mögen. Im Grunde sind beide Spiele eine Geschichte im ziemlich fiesen Cliffhanger. Jeder, der First Chapter gespielt hat, sollte ich allerdings auch den zweiten Teil zulegen.

Zuerst möchte ich klarstellen, das es genau die gleichen Positivpunkte wie Chapter 1 enthält, obwohl beide Stories relativ verschieden aufgebaut sind. Während First Chapter noch damit bemüht war, die Charaktere und die Welt, in der sie sich befinden, zu etablieren, sind wir hier schon etwas weiter. Im Gegensatz zum ersten Teil ist die Story hier mehr Plotgetrieben. Das ist nichts schlechtes, nur eben anders. 

Die Grafik und Welt sind großteils noch immer diesselben wie im ersten Teil, allerdings mit kleinen Verbesserungen und Anpassungen. Man kommt nochmals dazu, alle in First Chapter bekannten Gebiete und Orte zu besuchen. Die Kapitel 1-6 sind ziemlich ähnlich, und auch das Pacing ist ähnlich (langsam). Hat mich jetzt nicht besonders gestört, einigen Leuten könnte das aber langweilig werden. In diesen Kapiteln wird auch langsam die Antagonisten-Organisation, ihre Werte und Motive, vorgestellt. Die Protagonisten sind (mit einer Ausnahme) noch immer dieselben wie im ersten Teil. Im Verlauf der oben bereits erwähnten, ersten 5 Kapitel wird immer ein Antagonist vorgestellt, welcher als direkter Rivale für einen der Protagonisten zu sehen ist. In der Welt kann man sich noch immer verlieren, Landschaften und Städte sind für ein PSP-Spiel einfach wunderschön und glaubwürdig gestaltet.

Das allerwichtigste ist natürlich nicht die Story (wer hätte damit gerechnet), sondern die Interaktion der Charaktere miteinander und der für sie aufgesetzten Welt. Toll ist, wie es das Spiel schafft, über einen Zeitraum von knapp 100 Stunden (Erster und Zweiter Teil) jeden Charakter Tiefe zu verleihen. Jede noch so kleine Nebenperson bekommt ihre Zeit, ihren Antrieb zu ihren Taten, Vorlieben und Interessen zu zeigen und sich selbst weiterzuentwickeln. Man hat einfach das Gefühl, es nicht mit bloßen Anime-Stereotypen, sondern mit echten Menschen zu tun zu haben, die verletzlich sind, eigene Gefühle und Interessen haben, und auch ihre eigene Hürden im Verlauf der Geschichte überkommen zu haben. Sie treffen eigene Entscheidungen, und jede Entscheidung hilft mehr und mehr, den Charakter zu verstehen. Einfach toll gemacht!

Soundtechnisch hat sich nicht viel verändert. Es gibt einige aus dem ersten Teil bekannte Tracks, aber auch neue, auch gibt es eigene Themen für die jeweiligen Antagonisten. Vorallem die Kampf-Musik bleibt im Ohr und lässt sich auch super außerhalb des Spiels hören. 

Umfang: Das Spiel ist gigantisch. Als erstes PSP-Spiel, welches zwei UMDs benötigte, da auf einer einfach zu wenig Platz war, und mehr Text besitzt als ein Herr-der-Ringe Buch, kann ich nur sagen: Falcom, Hut ab! Vorallem, da das Spiel in gerademal zwei Jahren entstand.

Abschließend möchte ich sagen, wer bereits First Chapter großartig fand, hat gewissermaßen eine Obligation, auch den zweiten Teil zu spielen, da er  nicht nur die Hauptarc  um Estelle und Joshua zu einer sehr schönen Konklusion bringt, sondern auch den weniger wichtigen Charakteren Tiefe und Zeit gibt, sich zu entwickeln. (Mein Favorit: Die Geschichte von Mischas Tod!).

Very nice continuation of the First Chapter; do NOT play this game until you've finished The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky. You will be hopelessly lost without prior knowledge of characters and locations from the first game, and wiki summaries are simply not enough to bridge the gap.

The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky Second Chapter (or Eiyuu Densetsu: Sora no Kiseki SC in weebspeak) is quite simply one of the best games I've ever been sucked into. It's not perfect, but it comes close in pretty much every area.

The gameplay is as refreshing as ever; the battles are still on a tactical grid, where you and your enemies take turns to attack each other (and depending on how fast you are, you can potentially take multiple turns before your opponent even moves your way). However, there were several features added to the Trails in the Sky battle system. 
[list]
[*]The addition of combo crafts, where you and your whole party can gang up and wreak havoc on enemies is a fun feature, though outclassed towards the end of the game. 
[*]New spells are also available for use; if you detested Lt. Lorence spamming Silver Thorn on your ass, you can now do the same to those annoying monsters blocking your path, among other great spells.
[/list]
The overworld has a few minigames to help melt the time away, such as a casino and fishing. Fishing's especially something to note, since there's an achievement tied to it, if that's your thing.
Additionally, XSEED's even taken some PSP-exclusive content and backported it to the PC version. One of those features won't be seen until the end of the game, but it's worth the wait.

However, the overall story lacks a bit, especially when compared to FC's gradual but well-tempered buildup. Excluding the Prologue, every chapter from Chapter 1 up to and including Chapter 5 is rather formulaic in nature; strange happenings in a province lead to Estelle and friends investigating them, only to find out that an Ouroboros Enforcer is behind it all. 
The game picks up pace during Chapters 6 and 7, but leaves you at a pretty bad drop during Chapter 8 (which I can honestly say was my least favorite chapter in all the Trails games I've played, gameplay-wise). The Final Chapter more than makes up for the tedium of Chapter 8, however, and wraps up Estelle and Joshua's story very cleanly.

Speaking of which, the characters and dialogue in SC are top notch; while the plot may be  predictable at times, the characters more than make up for the lacking moments. 
Party members receive actual character development, and characters you may have despised in FC have a chance at redemption; Agate comes to mind easily. 
Additionally, new characters enter the fray, and they're just as good as the established characters; Kevin Graham, for one, is absolutely phenomenal in all the right ways.
Again, the dialogue flows naturally, and outside of one very, very small encounter in Zeiss, I couldn't help but eagerly read every line of dialogue that popped up. Even NPCs are relatively lively, which you might not expect from JRPGs; I've seen others where town NPCs get a single flavor line at best.

Lastly, the quality of the game is just perfect; I haven't encountered any technical issues at all, despite the somewhat troubled localization process. [spoiler]It even works quite well using Wine and/or WineSkin, if you're using Linux or OSX.[/spoiler] 

Here's to Trails in the Sky the 3rd, Trails of Cold Steel II, and hopefully Zero/Ao no Kiseki!

Time compels me to re-write my review, with more hindsight. I can no longer recommend this game. The more I think about it, the more frustrated it makes me. It's the biggest let-down I have experienced in gaming, because the first game was SO awesome, such an amazing JRPG that anyone even remotely into the genre should play. This game, despite being a direct sequel, despite working off of the same system, is not. I will give 2 basic reasons.

1) The game is frustrating. They wanted to continue this game off of the old one, they didn't want to invent an all new system or start you off at level 1 from scratch. Okay. But their attempt to "extend" everything, the leveling, the magic, your equipment, resulted in imbalance. It's too easy now to have an entire party dropping nukes on the battlefield. So their solution to this problem was frustration; simply make it hard to obtain money, magic "orbments", equipment, and constantly force-change your party with new characters who have different elemental restrictions, forcing different play styles (and sometimes, everything that was on the character you lost goes with them, if you didn't know to unequip them ahead of time). This game really requires multiple saves, in case they stick you with someone you have few options for and can hardly use. Fights themselves are now against bullet sponges who spam status effects, have random immunities, and heal themselves. Sometimes it's fun, but more often it just feels annoying, especially if, again, you "messed up" by not already having alot of a certain element so you could exploit weaknesses, even though you had no way of knowing that's what you needed. And good luck getting more, it takes HOURS. 

2) While I still like the characters, the banter, the moral dilemmas, the actual story is TERRIBLE. It's like The Empire Strikes Back, but if you had to watch Luke Skywalker getting completely owned by Vader over and over at the end of every act. Your enemy is, I don't know, Cobra, or Hydra, but not incompetent. Global reach, endless mooks, the most advanced technology, infinite money, full-scale mass production capabilities, unparalleled scientific and historical knowledge, all led by demi-gods, every one of which is able to backhand you into a coma without a thought. Why? I have no idea. Why does the second-in-command of this group have mind-control powers? I don't know. No one even asks. It's just accepted as perfectly fine to introduce a character with comic book powers with no origin story, no known limitations, he just can. It's laughable. There's no tension here; you CAN'T win. Just, lose, lose, lose. Every act is the same; something happens, you track down one of these humans of mythical power, you barely survive a fight and then they leave you alive out of pity. You stop nothing, you accomplish nothing, they could have simply removed most of the boss fights because they are a waste of time. 

A JRPG is really a combination of a few factors, mostly story and combat, and both fail. While I like many secondary aspects, like the world and characters (although alot of that we already know and is not as engaging the second time around), the important parts are just bad. The game is frustrating, it screws you over, it makes even scrub fights longer and more expensive than they have any need to be, and there is never any pay off for any of it, you're always losing. the equipment system, which was fun and mostly balanced before, is now horribly skewed in one direction and it really feels like tying a weight to your leg when the game gives you one of the other characters who can't exploit that imbalance. Finally, I didn't finish the game; the main story right before you reach the point of no return requires you to deliberately gimp yourself. I did so, only afterwards realizing that this was also the last chance to do about 50 sidequests, which I physically could not do now that I had weakened myself. I had no way of knowing this, and now I had no way of doing any of this optional content. I rage-quit. Maybe the last 3 hours of the story are awesome, but I really, really doubt it. Only fans of the previous game should even consider this entry, and even then, it's really, really a let down.

22288568.review:
[i]No one's looking. Cry as long as you want.
And I'll... just hold you like this.[/i]

Fans of the original Trails in the Sky have long awaited this almost ill-fated sequel, not only is the painfully long wait over, but it is exactly what we all wanted to see and more. Trails SC continues the story of the first game and far exceeds expectations in terms of story.

The gameplay is essentially identical to the first game with the addition of Chain Crafts, which allow multiple characters to attack in the same turn at the expense of some of their CP, and a new Orbment system which balances the magic system a bit and allows for more and better magic. The new Orbment system requires slots to be upgraded after unlocked in order to use more powerful Quartz, some of this better Quartz is either improvements of older ones, combination of two effects or brand new ones. The Orbment menu is now thankfully color-coded to know which line you're putting Quartz in and aids to better visualize the Sephith sums of each line. Other than that the game also adds a fishing minigame and some gambling minigames at the casino in Ruan for your leisure. The Bracer Guild quests are back and the game still follows the same chapter structure but allows you to edit your party as long as the plot dictates that they can be in your party. The battles have improved slightly with shorter attack animations, improved Crafts, new S-Crafts and encounters that force you to devise new strategies.

Graphically the game is exactly the same as its predecessor. HD assets and almost every PSP exclusive feature are available from the beginning. In the sound department we have new songs in combination with older ones that add up to a really expansive soundtrack. The new music exclusive to SC is fantastic and probably far better than its predecessor, with more rocking tunes and even the relaxing new ones have a better feel more suited to the current plotline and a final boss theme that might as well be one of the best in the series.
Unfortunately, updating a 2006 game to new standards has also included a slew of bugs. While there are workarounds for every bug I’ve managed to get stuck in some places and in the worst case I accidentally did a sequence break and skipped a major boss fight altogether. The translation also feels spotty at times but with the huge amount of text there is I’m willing to let it pass. Treasure chest jokes are unfortunately missing for the most part.

Just like its predecessor, the plot takes the spotlight in this game and I’d even say outright steals the entire show. Right from the beginning stakes are higher as the story continues right after where FC left off, we join Estelle as she looks for Joshua and tries to become a stronger and better Bracer while getting an insight on the mysterious group “Ouroboros”. Even though the pace remains rather slow, in every chapter our heroes face bigger threats compared to those of the first game and a lot of conflicts that were subtly hinted in the first game unfold. Even the sidequests are a step-up since they no longer involve such menial tasks since now the world is in danger and quite a few involve subplots essential to the world-building of the game. Trails SC is a lengthier affair than the first game, clocking at around 40-60 hours in an average play, with a New Game+ available and various difficulty modes if you ever want to replay it.

There isn’t a lot to say about Trails SC that hasn’t been said in reviews of the previous game other than “it’s bigger and better”. If you enjoyed the first game then SC is a must play, if you didn’t then you probably are missing out on a truly exceptional traditional RPG, one that took a long time to arrive and is worth every second and penny invested into it.
